This evening, I delivered my closing argument against Democrats' federal takeover of elections and their shameful attempt to break the rules to ram this misguided bill through the Senate. Both efforts ultimately failed. That’s good news for Americans. https://t.co/DfW4hfevkm

But their latest attempt to federalize elections was never about voting rights. It was about permanently stacking the deck in their favor at the expense of fair and secure elections – the foundation of our democracy.
This time, Democrats falsely claimed states are cracking down on voting rights. They aren’t. They’re making it easier to vote than ever.
Democrats have tried and failed over the past 20 years to pass massive, partisan elections legislation. The policies don’t change, only the false arguments used to justify them.

On the Senate floor speaking in opposition to Democrats' election takeover proposals. We must reject this partisan power grab and get back to the bipartisan cooperation that for so long previously defined the Senate.

Democrats are attempting to impose a federal takeover of elections and force a one-size-fits-all approach on every single one of the more than 10,000 voting jurisdictions in this country.

This will make our election system less secure.
Democrats keep repeating their false claims that state legislatures are passing restrictive voting laws. Here’s the truth: state legislatures are making it easier than ever to vote.
Democrats have, over the past 20+ years, repeatedly invented new justifications to push for a partisan, federal takeover of elections. Their current effort is nothing new. https://t.co/t0TR0s5orB
Our election system should not be turned upside down because one political party thinks legislation would give it an electoral advantage.

Democrats’ proposals have nothing to do with the right to vote and everything to do with the kinds of rules they think will help Democrats win future elections.

Even Senator Schumer admitted it. 

 https://t.co/pF1mtbwOgG

For 20 years, I served as an election official. I know firsthand that the diversity of our election system is its strength – making it virtually impossible to rig a nationwide election.

Democrats' federal election takeover proposals would undermine this.
Democrats’ push to break the Senate has nothing to do with voting rights. It is a one-party power grab.

Democrats’ proposals aren’t about voting rights. 

They’re about Democrats wanting to stack the deck to keep themselves in power.
The bottom line is that Democrats’ proposals have nothing to do with the right to vote, and everything to do with the kinds of rules they think will help them win future elections.
Let’s also not forget that many Republican states, like Arizona, Florida and Georgia, had already implemented no-excuse absentee voting.

States like Iowa and Georgia implemented more early voting days than even the Democrats would require in their so-called Freedom to Vote Act. In fact, these states have more days of early voting than many states with Democrat-led state legislatures, like New York & Connecticut.

The truth is that state legislatures are making voting easier than ever. Many states, including Georgia and Florida, now include specific provisions in state law that allow for the use of drop boxes, where no drop box provisions existed before.

Georgia’s previous deadline was shorter than the U.S. Postal Service recommendation. Georgia also removed a subjective signature verification requirement and replaced it with an objective voter ID requirement.

In Utah, the state legislature determined that it was a good idea to remove dead people from the voter rolls. In Georgia, the state legislature adjusted their mail-in ballot deadline to ensure voters who requested a mail-in ballot got their ballots with enough time to cast them.
Democrats have repeatedly claimed that state legislatures are passing restrictive voting laws. So what would these laws actually do? 🧵

We knew the process was unfair, but we learned last week that it’s even worse than that. Newly-released emails, made public under a court order, show the process was deliberately designed to deny patients in the Midwest & South their fair chance at a lifesaving liver transplant.

We've repeatedly challenged the process by which the changes came about. The organization that oversees liver allocations, UNOS, overruled transplant experts, excluded certain comments from the deliberations & arrived at a significantly different outcome than they had previously.

Over the past 3 years, Sen. @JerryMoran and I have fought changes to the national liver allocation policy that benefitted certain states at the expense of patients in the South and Midwest, including where we live.

The Department of Health and Human Services must immediately reverse its implementation of the misguided liver allocation policy. https://t.co/IqblMMmXEB

Sen. @JerryMoran and I have repeatedly said the process and policy for determining liver allocations needs to be made fairly and transparently. Neither UNOS nor the Department of Health and Human Services have lived up to this standard.
The emails further include profane and disparaging comments about people living in the South, demonstrating a clear bias against these areas in the policymaking process.
The changes favored certain states at the expense of states in the South and Midwest, which are predicted to see a substantial decrease in organ availability.

After reviewing emails that were just released between UNOS and organ procurement organizations and transplant hospitals, we now know that there was a pattern of collusion prior to the changes in the liver allocation policy being announced.

We knew that UNOS overruled the expert Liver and Intestine Committee, excluded certain public comments in the deliberations, and arrived at an outcome that was radically different from the decision previously reached.

Thanks to a recent appeals court ruling against UNOS, we have now learned that the process was more than just fundamentally flawed – it was deliberately designed to deny people in the South and Midwest a fair chance at a lifesaving liver transplant.

Three years ago, the United Network for Organ Sharing made major, misguided changes to the national liver allocation policy. Since that time, Sen. @JerryMoran and I have repeatedly raised the alarm about the new policy and the deeply flawed process by which it came about.
